page.title: 13Abbots Park,Cornwood(2)
page.content: Today,1985,Abbots Park is planned and landscaped with its carefully tended gardens and background of hills and moor:no modern housing-estate for many miles around could equal it.Modern timber-preservation methods and mater- ials have successfully driven off,not only the wood-boring beetles,but also bats and swifts.Neither common,nor black,redstarts now come this way. Insecticides have decimated the butter flies.Swallows and martins are reduced to a few pairs.At night,the tawny owl may still be heard,but the bloodchill- ing scream of the barn owl is heard no more, due to loss of nesting-sites. Some species adapt & survive.Buzzards still soar overhead,and the spring song of blackbirds,robins,dunnocks, wrens & a few thrushes can still be heard,although the dawn-chorus is much diminished.
